body.p: I write to request you to perform funeral service over the body of my lamented friend and Father-in-law. at your church in Georgetown ^tomorrow at 11 oclock^ The reason of my late application will be explained to you by my friend who hands you this and I know will be appreciated by you.
I know the task will be an embarassing one to you but I feel that you will not let the body of such go begging the rites of Christian burial.

George W. Johnson was born in this county on the spot where J Junius R Ward's house stands. May 27 1811. He died as we can best learn on Wednesday April 9 just having been mortally wounded on the 7th. I know through a confederate prisoner that he saw him fall. That he was on Breckenridges staff till a short time before his wound, when his horse being killed under him (not the day before) he immediately fell into the ranks with a gun
and was in a short time wounded.
Judge Duvall & Paul Rankin can give you any incidents in his life and character you desire
A brief discourse only will suffice though should you act I shall leave everything in regard to it entirely to your own judgement.
I shall be in town by 9 oclock and I hope I will not be disappointed in my expectations
Pardon this hurried note and believe me

Very truly Yours &c
J. Stoddard Johnston
to Elder McGinn of Versailles, minister in the christian church, who accepted the invitation to preach the funeral discourse over Mr Johnson-
Yourself and family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral of GEO. W. JOHNSON, from the Baptist Church, in this place, to-morrow, Friday morning at 11 o'clock.
A funeral discourse will be delivered on the occasion
